Title: Why does $p^2+8$ prime imply $p^3+4$ prime
Content: How do I prove that $p^2+8$ prime implies that $p^3+4$ is prime? What is the general pattern of thought for these problems?
AcceptedAnswer: If prime $p\ne 3,p$ can be written as $3k\pm1$ where $k$ is a positive integer. So, $p^2+8=(3k\pm1)^2+8=3(3k^2\pm2k+3)$ is divisible by $3$ and $>3$ hence composite. So, we are left with only one prime value of $p,$ i..e, $3$ More generally, $p^2+3m-1$ is composite for any positive integers $m$ and $3\not\mid p$ When we have found $3$ can be only value of prime $p,$ we can have umpteen prime numbers like $p^3+4,p^3+10,p^3-2,\cdots, p^4\pm2,\cdots $
